subject: RE: [junit] JUnit Anti-patterns
msgSnippet: Joe, In JUnit, we have a few tests that check the error messages. Mostly, though, all I care about is that potential users will see the correct kind of
messageBody:
Joe,

In JUnit, we have a few tests that check the error messages. Mostly, though,
all I care about is that potential users will see the correct kind of
exception.

Take care,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of J. B. Rainsberger
> Sent: Tuesday, February 28, 2006 5:10 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Anti-patterns
>
> Kent Beck wrote:
>
> > Re: code that throws exceptions. I prefer to declare the
> test case as
> > throwing the exception. I haven't ever had trouble
> debugging from the
> > information provided in the exception. Discarding that
> exception and getting
> > a generic AssertionError seems a step backwards to me.
>
> How often have you wished your test verified data stored in
> the expected
> exception? Ever? This is the one bit that surprises me,
> because I often
> want to check more than merely catching an instanceof the
> expected type.
> Can you think of a time when you would have preferred, in
> retrospect, to
> have checked more than just the exception type? I imagine not
> frequently
> enough to matter to you, judging only by what I've seen you
> write on the
> subject.
> --
